A Digital Guide to Archival Perfumery and Medicial Mixtures

The Druggist's Handbook of Private Formulas was published in 1882 by John H. Nelson.The text is crafted for druggists and readers interested in preparing medicines by providing formulas. While adopting a highly scientific form, its recipe-style presentation also enhances accessibility for laypeople to duplicate. The original version has undergone revisions and has been republished in recent years, with various editions released between 2008 and 2020. However, without access to these newer versions, it remains unclear whether the original content has been modernized or retained in its original form.

We aim to broaden the accessibility of the book to include medical or pharmaceutical students and science teachers interested in the teaching of how to make medicines. The specific section we plan to enhance runs from page 100, Sachet Powders, to page 111, Drops, encompassing the preface and serving as the transition from perfumes to proprietary medicines. While preserving the original recipe style in the digital edition, our focus is on providing more comprehensive explanations for terminologies by modernizing the text through adding contemporary meaning or explanations.

The object of this little volume is to place before every druggist reliable formulas for preparing well-kown medicines not given in the U.S. Dispensatory or Pharmacopoeia. These preparations Exlixirs, Emulsions, Medicated Syrups and Wines, etc.have become so universal that there is scarcely a druggist within the length and breadth of the land who does not have more or less sale for them; and to be enabled to prepare them is not only a source of satisfaction, but is also very desirable on account of the increase of profits.

In the other respective departments the dormulas will be found to be reliable, and can be depended upon. In fact, all the formulas contained in the work are "practical." They have been prepared again and again, and never failed to produce the desired result if carefully com- pounded.

The weights and measures used in the formulas are those adopted by the Pharmaceutical Association (they will be found in the Appendix to this work). The fluidounce is to be considered, 11 not otherwise directed, and the pound is always to be understood as consisting of twelve ounces. The directions for maceration or displacement, percolation, specific gravity, with other general information, being so plaintly set forth in the U.S. Dispensatory at the beginning of Part Second of that work, it is unnecessary to produce them here.

      1. PERFUME

      1.1. SACHET POWDERS

      [Page 100]

      1.1.1. 293
      frangipanni sachet

        Ground Sandalwood, 1 1/2 ounces

        Powdered Orris Root, 8 ounces

        Ground Tonka Bean, 1/2 ounce

        Oil of Rose, 5 drops

        Oil of Neroli, 3 drops

      Mix them in a mortar very thoroughly.


      1.1.2. 294
      heliotrope sachet

        Powdered Oriss Root, 1/2 pound

        Rose Leaves, ground, 4 ounces

        Tonka Bean, ground, 2 ounces

        Vanilla Bean, 1 ounce

        Grain Musk, 30 grains

        Oil of Bitter Almond, 1 drop

      Mix them


      1.1.3. 295
      millefleurs sachet.

        Powdered Orris Root, 4 ounces

        Powdered Benzoin, 4 ounces

        Ground Lavender Flowers, 4 ounces

        Ground Rose Leaves, 4 ounces

        Ground Tonka Bean, 1 ounce

        Ground Vanilla Bean, 1 ounce

        [Page 101]Ground Cloves, 1 ounce

        Ground Mace, 1/2 ounce

        Ground Cinnamon, 1 ounce

        Ground Allspice, 1/2 ounce

        Ground Sandalwood, 1 ounce

      Mix them by sifting.

      1.2. 296
      lavender sachet

        Lavender Flowers, ground, 1/2 pound

        Powdered Orris Root, 2 ounces

        Oil of Lavender, 1/4 ounce

      Mix them.


      1.3. 297
      potpourri

        Lavander Flowers, 4 ounces

        Orris Root, crushed, 2 ounces

        Cloves, crushed, 1 ounce

        Mace, crushed, 1 ounce

        Cinnamon, crushed, 1 ounce

        Allspice, crushed, 1 ounce

        Rose Leaves, crushed, 4 ounces

        Table Salt, 4 ounces

      Mix them.


      1.4. 298
      rose sachet

        Rose Leaves, ground, 4 ounces

        Sandalwood, ground, 2 ounces

        Oil of Rose, 1 drachm

        Powdered Orris Root, 1 ounce

      Mix them.

      1.5. pungents

      [Page 102]

      1.5.1. 299
      aromatic acetic acid

        Glacial Acetic Acid, 1 pound

        Oil of Cloves, 1 1/2 drachms

        Oil of Rosemary, 1 drachm

        Oil of Bergamot, 1 1/2 drachm

        Oil of Cinnanom, 1/2 drachm

        Oil of Peppermint, 1/2 drachm

        Oil of Lavender, 1/2 drachm

        Oil of Neroli, 20 drops

        Gum Camphor, 2 1/2 ounces

        Alcohol, 1 1/2 ounces

      Dissolve the Camphor and the Oils in the Alcohol. Melt the Acid, and add the solution to it.


      1.6. 300
      sal volatile

        Liquor Ammoniae, 1 pint

        Oil of Rosemary, 8 drops

        Oil of Bergamot, 8 drops

        Oil of Cloves, 4 drops

        Oil of Lavender, 8 drops

      Mix them.

      [Page 103]

      1.7. 301
      preston salts

        Carbonate of Ammonium, 1 ounce

        Oil of Lavender, 5 drops

        Oil of Lemon, 2 drops

        Oil of Cloves, 1 drops

      Mix them.


      1.8. 302
      essense for smelleing bottle

        Oil of Lavender, 1 drachm

        Spirit of Bergamot, 1 drachm

        Oil of Orange, 8 drops

        Oil of Cinnamon, 4 drops

        Oil of Neroli, 2 drops

        Alcoholn, 4 ounces

        Water of Ammonia, 4 ounces

      Mix them.


      1.9. fumigators


      1.9.1. 303
      fumigating pastilles.

        Powdered Gum Benzoin, 2 ounces

        Powdered Cascarilla, 2 ounces

        Powdered Myrrth, 1 ounce

        Powdered Nitrate of Potassium, 1/2 ounce

        Powdered Cholarate of Potassium, 1 drachm

        Powdered Charcoal, 4 ounces

        Oil of Cloves, 1 drachm

        Oil of Cinammon, 1 drachm

        [Page 104]Oil of Lavender, 1 drachm

        Alcohol, 1 1/2 ounces

        Mucilage of Tragacanth, a sufficient quantity

      Mix them all thoroughtly; then form into a paste with the Tragacanth. Make into cones immediately, and set them aside to dry.


      1.10. 304
      incense powder.

        Powdered Gum Galbanum, 1 pound

        Powdered Nitrate of Potassium, 1 ounce

      Mix them.


      1.11. 305
      holy incense powder.

        Ground Gum Benzoin, 1/4 pound

        Ground Cascarilla Bark, 1/4 pound

        Ground Sandalwood, 1/2

        Powdered Nitrate of Potaassium, 1 ounce

        Grain Music, 1o grains

      Mix the ingredients thoroughly. To be kept in an air-tight vessel. Used in Roman Catholic churches and Jewish synagogues.

      [Page 105]

      2. proprietary madicine


      2.1. balsams


      2.1.1. 306
      lung balsams

      [Page 106]

      2.2. bitters

      [Page 109]

      2.3. cures


      2.3.1. 315
      asthma cure

        Belladonna Leaves, 2 ounces

        Stramonium Leaves, 1 ounces

        Powdered Nitrate of Potassium, 1 1/2 drachms

      Mix them thoroughly. To be used by igniting a drachm in a suitable vessel, and inhaling the fumes.


      2.3.2. 316
      cararrh cure

        Carbolic Acid, pure, 1 drachm

        Glycerine, 4 drachms

        Distilled Water, 1 drachm

        Fluid Extract of Stramonium, 2 drachms

      Mix them. Dilute one drachm of the mixture with four ounces of water, and use with a nasal douche.


      2.3.3. 317
      consumption cure

        Syrup of Morphia, 4 ounces

        Chloroform, C.P., 1/2 fluidounce

        Glycerine, 3 1/2 fluidounces

        Hydrocyanic Acid, dilute, 1 drachm

      Mix the Chloroform with the Glycerine; add the other ingredients, and mix. Dose, a teaspoonful.

      [Page 110]

      2.3.4. 318
      dyspepsia cure

        Powdered Rhubarb, 2 drachms

        Bicarbonate of Sodium, 6 drachms

        Fluid Extract of Gentian, 3 drachms

        Peppermint Water, 17 1/2 ounces

      Mix them. Dose, a teaspoonful half an hour before meals.

      2.4. discovery


      2.4.1. 319
      a great discovery

        Fluid Extract of Cinchona, U.S., 16 ounces

        Fluid Extract of Columbo, U.S., 4 ounces

        Fluid Extract of Guaiacum, U.S., 8 ounces

        Fluid Extract of Liquorice, U.S., 4 ounces

        Podophyllin, 120 grains

        Alcohol, a sufficient quantity

        Glycerine, 6 pints, fluid

      Dissolve the Podophyllin in the Alcohol, and add the rest of the ingredients. Mix them. Dose, a teaspoonful.

      2.5. dose


      2.5.1. 320
      tapeworm dose

        Pumpkin Seeds, 1 1/2 ounces

        Powdered Sugar, 1 ounce

        Powdered Gum Arabic, 6 drachms

        Cinnamon Water, 8 ounces

      [Page 111]

      Remove the external coat from the Pumpkin Seeds, and beat into a pulp; then add the Sugar and Powdered Gum Arabic, thoroughly incorporating them. Pour on the Cinnamon Water slowly, stirring constantly until emulsi- fied. Take four ounces for a dose in the morning on an empty stomach (having omitted supper and breakfast). One hour after taking the dose, take one drachm of Oil of Male Fern in half an ounce of Mucilage of Gum Arabic. One hour afterwards, take the remainder of the dose. Then in about an hour take one ounce of Castor Oil. The dose to be freshly made as wanted.

      2.6. drops


      2.6.1. 321
      hamburg drops

        Powdered Socotrine Aloes, 3 ounces

        American Saffron, 1 ounce

        Tincture of Myrrh, 32 ounces

      Macerate for fourteen days, and filter through paper. Dose, one to two teaspoonfuls.


      2.6.2. 322
      toothache drops

        Powdered Gum Camphor, 1 ounce

        Chloral Hydrate, 1 ounce

      Rub them together in a Wedgwood mortar until they liquefy. Apply to the cavity on a small piece of cotton.

      Note: Waterless Acetic Acid, also know as concentrated or pure vinegar
      Note: Ethanol or Isopropyl alcohol
      Note: Ammonia solution
      Note: A disease that affects your lungs.
      Note: A toxic perennial herbaceous plant in the nightshade family Solanaceae.
      Note: Bergamot Oil, also known as bergamot essential oil
      Note: A byproduct of your body's metabolism.
      Note: A very poisonous chemical substance made from tar and also found in some plants and essential oils.
      Note: Ammonium Carbonate in solid form
      Note: Powdered egg shells, freely available
      Note: Bark of the Cascarilla plant
      Note: A build-up of mucus in an airway or cavity of the body.
      Note: Lightweight black carbon
      Note: A sedative used in the short-term treatment of insomnia.
      Note: Potassium Chlorate
      Note: A colorless liquid that quickly evaporates into gas. Can harm the eyes, skin, liver, kidneys, and nervous system.
      Note: A genus of flowering plants in the family Rubiaceae.
      Note: Cinamon Oil, also know as cinnamon essential oil
      Note: Clove Oil, also know as clove essential oil
      Note: A herbaceous perennial of the gentian family Gentianaceae.
      Note: Discomfort in your upper abdomen.
      Note: also known as plumeria or spelled as frangipani
      Note: Fumigators:a person or thing that fumigates
      Note: A genus of flowering plants belonging to the gentian family.
      Note: A type of carbohydrate known as a sugar alcohol or a polyol.
      Note: From Musk Pod where liquid is dried
      Note: A genus of flowering plants in the caltrop family Zygophyllaceae.
      Note: A gum exuded by some kinds of acacia.
      Note: From Benzoin tree, in a non-powdered form
      Note: A crystaline powder derived from turpentine
      Note: The gum resin from Galbanum herb plant
      Note: Blood purifier, strength and health restorer, and a specific for all stomach, liver and kidney troubles.
      Note: A rapidacting lethal agent that inhibits aerobic respiration at the cellular level, preventing cells from utilizing oxygen.
      Note: Incense:the perfume or smoke arising from such a substance when burned.
      Note: Lavender Oil, also known as Lavender essential oil
      Note: Lemon Oil, also known as Lemon essential oil
      Note: A flowering plant of the bean family Fabaceae, from the root of which a sweet, aromatic flavouring is extracted.
      Note: A solution of Ammonium carbonate, water and alcohol
      Note: Also called morphine, is a highly potent opiate analgesic drug.
      Note: A natural gum from Tragacanth tree
      Note: Resin from Comminiphora trees in ppowdered form, also known as myrrh resin powder or gun powder
      Note: Neroli Oil, also known as neroli essential oil or serum
      Note: Potassium Nitrate
      Note: Orange Oil, also known as orange essential oil or serum
      Note: From the root of Orris plant, available in original and powdered form
      Note: Peppermint oil, also known as peppermint essential oil
      Note: A cytotoxic material extracted from Podophyllum peltatum and Podophyllum hexandrum.
      Note: Typical Smelling salts
      Note: The fleshy, edible stalks of species and hybrids of Rheum in the family Polygonaceae.
      Note: Rosemary Oil, also known as rosemary essential oil
      Note: Rose Oil, also known as rose essential oil or serum
      Note: Sal Volatile: an aromatic alcoholic solution of ammonium carbonate, the chief ingredient in smelling salts
      Note: Sachet: a small bag, case, or pad containing perfuming powder or the like, placed among handkerchiefs, lingerie, etc., to impart a pleasant scent. Sachet Powder: the powder contained in such a case. Note: modern day sachet powders are often associated with magic and health benefits, these are likely just for scent
      Note: A spice derived from the flower of Crocus sativus.
      Note: Refers to sandalwood powder, derived from a widely cultivated tree of the same name, freely available
      Note: a species of plant in the genus Aloe.
      Note: A poisonous flowering plant of the nightshade family Solanaceae.
      Note: A parasite that can live and feed in human intestines.
      Note: A bean from Brazil, available but Vanilla is a common subsitute.
